On March 23, 2025, noncitizens D.V.D., M.M., E.F.D., and O.C.G. filed a class action in the U.S. District Court for Massachusetts, alleging the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its officials violated their legal rights by deporting individuals with final removal orders to third countries—countries not designated in their immigration proceedings—without providing notice or an opportunity to contest removal on grounds of persecution, torture, or death. The plaintiffs, represented by private attorneys and the National Immigration Litigation Alliance, argued that this policy breached the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act (FARRA), the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause, and U.S. treaty obligations under the Convention Against Torture (CAT). The proposed class included all noncitizens with final removal orders whom DHS had or would deport to third countries after February 18, 2025, under a controversial internal directive.  

The district court, presided over by Judge Brian E. Murphy, granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) on March 28, 2025, and later certified the class on April 18, 2025. The court issued a preliminary injunction requiring DHS to provide written notice of third-country removal in a language the individual understands, along with a meaningful opportunity to seek CAT protection. The injunction also mandated a 15-day window for motions to reopen immigration proceedings if a fear claim was denied.  

Defendants appealed, arguing the court lacked jurisdiction under 8 U.S.C. § 1252(g) and (b)(9) and that their procedures satisfied due process. The First Circuit denied a stay on May 16, 2025, and the Supreme Court granted a stay on June 23, 2025, pending resolution of the appeal. Despite this, the district court continued proceedings, including expedited discovery on whether O.C.G. received notice before his deportation to Mexico in February 2025. O.C.G., a Guatemalan man granted withholding of removal to Guatemala, was secretly deported to Mexico without warning, where he faced forced detention and potential return to Guatemala. The court found this violated the preliminary injunction and ordered DHS to facilitate his return, though this was later stayed by the Supreme Court.  

Plaintiffs moved for partial summary judgment in July 2025, asserting DHS’s policy is unlawful. Defendants sought to stay the district court proceedings pending appeal, but the court denied the motion, emphasizing the need to address jurisdictional and procedural issues. As of August 1, 2025, the case remains pending, with the Supreme Court’s stay in effect. The plaintiffs continue to challenge the constitutionality of third-country removals, while defendants argue for deference to executive authority and compliance with existing administrative processes.

In February 2025, plaintiffs—including Ukrainian, Nicaraguan, Afghan, and other nationals paroled into the U.S. under humanitarian programs, U.S. citizen sponsors, and the Haitian Bridge Alliance—filed a class action in the U.S. District Court for Massachusetts. They alleged that the Trump administration unlawfully terminated categorical parole programs and suspended immigration benefit adjudications for parolees, violating the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The plaintiffs argued that parole under 8 U.S.C. § 1182(d)(5) allows temporary entry for “urgent humanitarian reasons” or “significant public benefit,” which had been historically applied on a programmatic basis by administrations of both parties.  

On January 20, 2025, President Trump signed executive orders directing the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to terminate categorical parole programs and review parole policies. That day, Acting Secretary Benjamine Huffman issued a memorandum claiming such programs were “blatantly inconsistent with the statute.” In March 2025, DHS published a Federal Register Notice terminating the CHNV programs, which allowed parole for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans, and rescinding parole grants issued under these programs by April 24, 2025, without case-by-case review. USCIS also paused adjudicating immigration benefits (e.g., asylum, TPS) for parolees, citing incomplete vetting.  

Plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to block these actions, arguing irreparable harm from losing legal status and work authorization. The district court granted partial relief, staying the mass termination of CHNV parole and certifying a class of affected parolees and sponsors. On May 30, 2025, the Supreme Court granted a stay of the district court’s order pending appeal, allowing DHS to proceed with terminations. The case remains ongoing, with plaintiffs challenging the legality of the policies as arbitrary and capricious and inconsistent with the INA’s text and historical interpretation.  

The suit highlights plaintiffs’ reliance on parole programs to avoid dangerous border crossings, reunite families, and seek protection from persecution. Defendants countered that parole terminations were discretionary and lawful under the statute, with the district court’s jurisdiction barred by 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(2)(B). The conflict underscores tensions between executive authority to manage immigration and judicial oversight of agency actions.

On February 25, 2025, the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), American Sociological Association (ASA), AFT-Maryland, and later Eugene School District 4J (District 4J) filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Education (DOE), Secretary Linda McMahon, and Acting Assistant Secretary Craig Trainor. The plaintiffs alleged that a February 14, 2025, DOE Dear Colleague Letter (the Letter) and a subsequent certification requirement (the Certification) violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), First Amendment (free speech and association), and Fifth Amendment (vagueness).  

The Letter purported to clarify Title VI of the Civil Rights Act and the Supreme Court’s 2023 Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) decision, banning practices it deemed "race-based discrimination." It criticized teaching about systemic racism, diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs, and student groups tied to race or ethnicity, asserting such activities created hostile environments. The plaintiffs argued the Letter reinterpreted Title VI to prohibit lawful educational practices, such as culturally responsive teaching, history curricula addressing racial discrimination, and student affinity groups, while failing to define key terms like "DEI" or "racially hostile environment." The Certification, sent to states and school districts on April 3, 2025, required affirmation of compliance with the Letter’s standards as a condition for federal funding.  

On April 24, 2025, the court granted a preliminary injunction against the Letter, finding it likely violated the APA by being a final agency rule issued without required notice-and-comment procedures and chilled protected speech. The Certification was not enjoined initially because the Amended Complaint lacked specific claims against it. After the plaintiffs added new counts in their Second Amended Complaint, the court ruled on August 14, 2025, vacating both the Letter and Certification. The court held the Letter and Certification were final legislative rules requiring APA compliance, issued without proper process and in conflict with existing law. The Certification also violated the Paperwork Reduction Act and imposed arbitrary, vague obligations. The ruling concluded that the documents unlawfully restricted curriculum and speech, forcing schools to self-censor or risk losing funding, investigations, or False Claims Act liability.  

The case ended with a judgment vacating the Letter and Certification, enjoining their enforcement, and rejecting the government’s argument that the actions merely restated existing law. The court emphasized that agencies must follow procedural requirements and not overstep statutory authority, even when implementing policy shifts aligned with a new administration’s priorities.

In *J. Doe 1-26 v. Elon Musk*, plaintiffs (current and former USAID employees and contractors) filed a complaint on February 13, 2025, alleging that Elon Musk, in his official capacity as a de facto leader of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), violated the U.S. Constitution’s Appointments Clause and separation of powers. Plaintiffs claimed Musk, who was not Senate-confirmed, exercised authority over USAID by directing the removal of senior staff, granting DOGE personnel unrestricted access to USAID systems (including sensitive personnel files), and implementing mass contract terminations and office closures. The complaint alleged that these actions disrupted humanitarian programs, jeopardized employee livelihoods, and breached privacy laws.  

On March 18, 2025, Judge Theodore D. Chuang granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining Musk and DOGE from accessing plaintiffs’ sensitive data, terminating employees or contracts, and dismantling USAID without authorization. The injunction also required reinstatement of system access and submission of a plan to restore USAID’s headquarters. Defendants appealed, arguing that Musk was a non-officer with no formal authority, and that USAID’s actions were taken by duly appointed officials. On March 28, the Fourth Circuit stayed the injunction pending appeal, finding plaintiffs had not named the actual decision-makers (e.g., USAID leadership) and that the district court’s order risked enjoining lawful executive functions.  

Plaintiffs amended their complaint on May 30, 2025, adding USAID and other officials as defendants and seeking class certification for all USAID employees and contractors affected during January 20–February 3, 2025. Defendants moved to dismiss on May 1, 2025, asserting jurisdictional bars under the Civil Service Reform Act and Contract Disputes Act, and that plaintiffs lacked standing. The district court had not yet ruled on the motion at the time of the appeal.  

The case centers on whether Musk’s role in DOGE constitutes an unconstitutional circumvention of the Appointments Clause and whether the executive branch exceeded its authority by dismantling USAID, an agency established by Congress. The Fourth Circuit’s stay remains in effect, preserving the status quo pending resolution of the appeal and district court proceedings.

On February 10, 2025, the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition (AVAC) and Journalism Development Network (JDN), non-profit organizations providing global health and journalism services, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the U.S. Department of State, USAID, OMB, and President Donald Trump. They challenged Executive Order 14169, issued by President Trump on January 20, 2025, which mandated a 90-day pause on foreign development assistance to review program efficiency and alignment with U.S. foreign policy. The order was implemented via directives from Secretary of State Marco Rubio, freezing funding for AVAC’s HIV prevention research and JDN’s anti-corruption journalism projects under existing grants and cooperative agreements.  

The plaintiffs alleged the freeze violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Take Care Clause of the Constitution, and the Impoundment Control Act, arguing Congress had appropriated funds without authorizing such a suspension. On February 13, the court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining the defendants from enforcing the freeze for existing contracts and grants, but permitted individualized terminations based on contract terms. Despite this, plaintiffs later moved to enforce the TRO, asserting continued non-compliance, including delayed payments and blanket terminations. The court ordered defendants to unfreeze funds for work completed before the TRO by February 26, 2025.  

Defendants appealed, seeking a stay, but the D.C. Circuit dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction over the TRO. The Supreme Court also denied a stay, directing the district court to clarify compliance timelines. On March 10, the district court issued a preliminary injunction, finding the freeze likely arbitrary and capricious under the APA and violating separation of powers. It required defendants to make all appropriated foreign aid funds available for obligation. Defendants moved to dismiss the amended complaints, arguing plaintiffs lacked standing and the APA did not authorize judicial review of impoundment claims.  

On August 13, 2025, the D.C. Circuit upheld the dismissal of plaintiffs’ constitutional and APA claims, ruling they lacked a cause of action to challenge executive impoundment of funds. The court emphasized that the Comptroller General, not private parties, holds authority under the Impoundment Control Act to enforce statutory obligations. The preliminary injunction was vacated, leaving defendants unencumbered to proceed with their restructuring of foreign aid programs.  

The case centered on the balance of congressional appropriations authority and executive discretion in foreign policy, with plaintiffs seeking to restore funding for humanitarian and democratic initiatives, and defendants asserting their statutory and constitutional authority to realign aid priorities.

In February 2025, plaintiffs—including individual refugees and nonprofit resettlement agencies—filed a class action lawsuit challenging Executive Order 14163, signed by President Trump on January 20, 2025. The order indefinitely suspended refugee admissions and processing under the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program (USRAP) and halted funding to resettlement partners. Plaintiffs argued this violated the Refugee Act of 1980 (8 U.S.C. § 1157 et seq.), the Administrative Procedure Act, and constitutional due process rights, particularly affecting follow-to-join (FTJ) petitioners and newly arrived refugees.  

On February 25, 2025, Judge Jamal N. Whitehead granted a preliminary injunction, blocking implementation of the order. The court found the suspension of refugee processing and funding was ultra vires, exceeding presidential authority under the INA, and arbitrary under the APA. The Ninth Circuit later partially stayed the injunction on March 25, 2025, excluding refugees conditionally approved before January 20, 2025, but clarified in April 2025 that the stay applied narrowly to cases with “strong reliance interests” comparable to lead plaintiff Pacito, whose family had sold possessions and lost housing after last-minute travel cancellations.  

Defendants moved to dismiss, arguing the APA did not apply to contract-based claims and that § 1182(f) of the INA granted the President unreviewable authority. The court rejected these arguments, emphasizing the statutory mandates for refugee resettlement and the Ninth Circuit’s requirement for case-by-case reliance assessments. In July 2025, the court established a compliance framework, appointing Magistrate Judge Michelle L. Peterson to oversee individualized determinations for refugees with confirmable travel plans canceled pre-EO.  

The case remains pending, with the preliminary injunction in effect for qualifying refugees. Related proceedings include consolidated cases (e.g., *Doe v. Trump*, 288 F. Supp. 3d 1045 (W.D. Wash. 2017)) and appeals to the Ninth Circuit (No. 25-1313). Plaintiffs seek to restore the USRAP’s statutory framework, while defendants assert broad executive discretion in immigration and foreign aid matters.

On February 7, 2025, the states of Washington, Minnesota, Oregon, and later Colorado, along with three physician plaintiffs, filed a lawsuit challenging Executive Orders 14,168 and 14,187 issued by President Donald J. Trump. The Medical Services EO (14,187) defined certain gender-affirming treatments for minors under 19 as “chemical and surgical mutilation” and directed federal agencies to immediately defund institutions providing such care. The Gender Ideology EO (14,168) mandated that federal grants not fund programs recognizing gender identities inconsistent with biological sex.  

Plaintiffs argued the EOs violated the Fifth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause, usurped Congressional spending authority under separation of powers principles, and infringed on states’ rights to regulate medicine under the Tenth Amendment. They sought injunctive relief to block enforcement, citing imminent harm to patients and institutions reliant on federal funding. Defendants countered that the EOs were within the President’s authority to direct agencies and that plaintiffs lacked standing due to unripe claims and no final agency action.  

On February 14, 2025, Judge Lauren King granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining enforcement of the Medical Services EO’s defunding provision. After a February 28 hearing, the court extended the injunction to the Gender Ideology EO’s funding restrictions but denied relief for the criminal enforcement provision (Section 8(a)). Defendants appealed and secured a stay of the preliminary injunction on April 23, 2025, pending resolution in the Ninth Circuit.  

The case centers on whether the EOs unconstitutionally discriminate against transgender youth, infringe on federalism principles, and overstep executive authority. Plaintiffs highlighted life-saving medical consensus and institutional reliance on federal grants, while defendants emphasized policy discretion and statutory compliance. Key related litigation includes a nationwide TRO issued in a parallel Maryland case. Discovery proceeded on claims of contempt after NIH terminated a grant to Seattle Children’s Hospital, though the court denied plaintiffs’ motion to hold defendants in contempt. The Ninth Circuit’s review of the preliminary injunction will determine the case’s next steps.

Trump et al.* (Case No. 8:25-cv-00337-BAH), plaintiffs including PFLAG, GLMA, and transgender minors and adults, along with their parents, sued the Trump administration over two Executive Orders: EO 14,168 (Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth) and EO 14,187 (Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation). Plaintiffs sought to enforce the injunction after agencies issued new notices in March 2025, which they argued renewed threats to federal funding for gender-affirming care. The case centers on whether the Executive Branch can override congressional appropriations and statutory non-discrimination mandates to restrict gender-affirming care. In March 2025, a group of legal service organizations (e.g., Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto, Florence Immigrant and Refugee Rights Project) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), its Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR), and the Department of the Interior (DOI) violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by abruptly terminating funding for legal representation of unaccompanied children in immigration proceedings. The plaintiffs, represented by Immigrant Defenders Law Center, Amica Center for Immigrant Rights, and Justice Action Center, argued that the termination conflicted with the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA) and ORR’s 2024 Foundational Rule, which mandate that HHS ensure legal counsel for such children “to the greatest extent practicable.”

The plaintiffs claimed this left thousands of unaccompanied children—many infants or toddlers—without legal guidance for asylum, trafficking protections, or other relief. The district court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) on April 1, 2025, enjoining the government from cutting off funding, and extended it to April 30 after a motion for recusal was denied. The Ninth Circuit initially dismissed the appeal as non-appealable but later allowed a petition for rehearing en banc. The panel denied the stay pending appeal, affirming the district court’s jurisdiction and the plaintiffs’ likelihood of success in showing the cancellation order was arbitrary and capricious. The government’s motion to recuse the district judge (Araceli Martinez-Olguin) for prior ties to a plaintiff and potential bias was denied.  

The case highlights a conflict over statutory interpretation: the plaintiffs assert the government is legally obligated to use available congressional appropriations (up to $5 billion through 2027) to fund legal services, while the government claims discretion to allocate resources and terminate contracts under its authority. The district court’s nationwide injunction preserves funding for legal representation, but the government seeks to vacate it, citing separation of powers concerns and the risk of irrecoverable taxpayer expenditures. The litigation remains ongoing, with the Ninth Circuit’s en banc decision pending.

In *Shilling v. United States* (Case No. 2:25-cv-241-BHS), transgender service members and the Gender Justice League sued the U.S. government to challenge Executive Order 14183 (the “2025 Military Ban”), which prohibits individuals who are transgender or exhibit symptoms of gender dysphoria from serving in the military. Plaintiffs, represented by Perkins Coie LLP, Lambda Legal, and the Human Rights Campaign, alleged violations of the Fifth Amendment’s Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses and the First Amendment’s Free Speech protections. They sought a preliminary injunction to block enforcement of the policy, arguing it lacks rational or compelling justification and violates their rights by discharging qualified service members based solely on transgender status.  

The case was filed on February 6, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, where Judge Benjamin H. Settle presided. Plaintiffs included seven active-duty transgender service members (e.g., Commander Emily Shilling, with over 19 years of Navy service and 60 combat missions) and one aspiring enlistee, Matthew Medina. Defendants included the U.S. government, the Department of Defense, and senior military officials in their official capacities. The court granted the preliminary injunction on March 27, 2025, finding plaintiffs likely to succeed on their claims and concluding the policy failed intermediate scrutiny. The injunction barred implementation of the ban nationwide, preserving the prior Biden-era policy allowing transgender service under specific medical criteria.  

Defendants appealed to the Ninth Circuit, seeking to stay the injunction, and later filed an emergency application for a stay with the Supreme Court. The Ninth Circuit denied the stay on March 31, 2025, and the Supreme Court’s docket reflects ongoing review. The case is linked to parallel lawsuits, including *Talbott v. United States* (D.D.C.) and *Ireland v. Hegseth* (D.N.J.), both addressing similar challenges to the 2025 Military Ban. The government argued the policy is a legitimate exercise of military judgment to ensure readiness, cohesion, and cost efficiency, citing medical literature and prior policies. Plaintiffs countered that the ban is driven by animus and contradicts decades of military data showing no adverse impact from transgender service under the 2016 Carter Policy and 2021 Austin Policy.  

The district court’s March 27 order emphasized the absence of evidence supporting the ban’s asserted justifications, noting no complaints about unit cohesion or readiness under the previous policies. Defendants’ motion to stay pending appeal highlighted the military’s need to enforce its policy to maintain operational effectiveness, while plaintiffs warned that the ban would irreparably harm service members and undermine diversity in the armed forces. Individual plaintiffs, noncitizens expecting children after the Order’s February 19, 2025 implementation date, alleged the Order would strip their children of citizenship, exposing them to deportation and denying them rights like voting and working. The district court granted a temporary restraining order and later a preliminary injunction, blocking the Order’s enforcement nationwide. It ruled the states had standing based on their sovereign and proprietary interests in federal funding and concluded the Order likely conflicted with the Constitution and INA.  

Defendants appealed, arguing the injunction improperly extended to nonparties and that states lacked standing to assert individual rights. The Ninth Circuit initially denied a stay, but the Supreme Court later held in *Trump v. CASA, Inc.* (June 2025) that universal injunctions exceeding the scope of the plaintiffs’ injuries were impermissible. However, the Court left open whether such injunctions could apply to states’ own injuries. On remand, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction against the Order, holding the states’ financial and administrative harms were concrete and directly traceable to the Order. The court rejected arguments that the harms were speculative or self-inflicted, emphasizing the states’ reliance on federal reimbursement for programs.  

The case proceeded as a class action for the individual plaintiffs, though their claims were dismissed due to overlap with a certified class in another district. The states’ challenge to the Order’s legality remained active, with the court upholding the injunction as necessary to prevent harm to their programs. The defendants did not dispute the constitutional guarantee of citizenship for the individual plaintiffs but maintained the Order was lawful under the President’s authority to define jurisdictional limits. The Ninth Circuit’s final opinion (July 2025) concluded the Order contradicted the plain text of the Fourteenth Amendment and INA, affirming the injunction’s validity for the states’ claims.
results.45965:
On January 21, 2025, CASA, Inc., Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project, and five pregnant women with non-citizen immigration statuses filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland challenging Executive Order 14,160, issued by President Donald J. Trump. The order sought to deny birthright citizenship to children born in the U.S. to mothers who were either unlawfully present or lawfully present on temporary visas, and whose fathers were not U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents. Plaintiffs argued the order violated the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and 8 U.S.C. § 1401(a), which guarantee citizenship to all children born in the U.S. and subject to its jurisdiction.  

The district court, presided over by Judge Deborah L. Boardman, granted a nationwide preliminary injunction on February 5, 2025, blocking enforcement of the order. The court found the plaintiffs had a strong likelihood of success on the merits, citing the Supreme Court’s 1898 decision in *Wong Kim Ark*, which affirmed birthright citizenship regardless of parents’ immigration status (except for narrow exceptions like children of diplomats or enemy combatants). The court also emphasized the irreparable harm of denying citizenship to newborns, including statelessness and family separation.  

The government appealed to the Fourth Circuit and sought a partial stay of the injunction, arguing it improperly extended to nonparties. The Fourth Circuit denied the stay, but the Supreme Court granted partial stays on June 27, 2025, limiting injunctions to plaintiffs and prohibiting courts from enjoining the Executive Branch’s internal implementation efforts. The Court held universal injunctions lacked historical basis in equity and exceeded judicial authority.  

Following the Supreme Court’s directive, the district court certified a nationwide class on August 7, 2025, representing children born or expected to be born in the U.S. after February 19, 2025, whose parents’ immigration statuses fall under the executive order’s scope. Class representatives included CASA and ASAP members with pending asylum claims, temporary visas, or undocumented status. The court found Rule 23(b)(2) applicable, as the injunction sought to prevent the government from enforcing an allegedly unlawful policy affecting the entire class.  

The case remains pending on the merits, with the Supreme Court’s partial stays allowing the district court to refine the injunction’s scope to comply with Rule 23. The plaintiffs’ motion for a classwide preliminary injunction was granted, maintaining the status quo until the class certification is fully addressed. The government has not contested the constitutional and statutory claims on their merits, focusing instead on procedural limits of injunctive relief.  

Consolidated cases include *Washington v. Trump* (W.D. Wash.) and *New Jersey v. Trump* (D. Mass.), both granting nationwide injunctions. The Supreme Court’s decision emphasized that while universal injunctions are invalid, class actions under Rule 23 provide a lawful avenue for broad relief. The certified class here seeks to preserve birthright citizenship for U.S.-born children, ensuring access to citizenship benefits and preventing family disruption under the long-standing *Wong Kim Ark* precedent.
results.VR-LA-0120:
In *Clark v. Edwards* (Case No. 3:20-cv-00308-SDD-RLB) and consolidated *Power Coalition for Equity & Justice v. Edwards* (Case No. 3:20-cv-00283-SDD-RLB), plaintiffs—including individuals with health risks from COVID-19 and two organizations—sued Louisiana state officials, alleging that the state’s absentee voting laws violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments and the Voting Rights Act. The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to remove three restrictions: (1) the “Excuse Requirement” mandating specific reasons to vote by mail, (2) the “Witness Requirement” requiring a third party to sign absentee ballot envelopes, and (3) the “Cure Prohibition” denying voters notice and an opportunity to correct ballot defects.  

Plaintiffs argued that these provisions forced high-risk voters (e.g., elderly individuals, those with preexisting conditions) to choose between their health and voting, disproportionately impacting Black Louisianans due to systemic health and socioeconomic disparities. They cited epidemiological evidence of pandemic risks and compared Louisiana’s rules to more flexible systems in other states. The state defendants, including Governor Edwards, Secretary of State Ardoin, and Attorney General Landry, moved to dismiss, claiming plaintiffs lacked standing because the pandemic (not state action) caused the alleged harm and asserting that judicial intervention near elections would create chaos under the *Purcell doctrine*.  

The court dismissed the claims with prejudice. It held that plaintiffs failed to establish standing, as their injuries were not traceable to the defendants’ actions but rather to the virus itself. Additionally, the court found the cases moot for the July and August elections, which had adopted an “Emergency Election Plan” expanding absentee voting for some categories, and ruled that plaintiffs could not prove an unconstitutional condition for the November and December elections. The judgment closed the case, and plaintiffs’ motion to amend the dismissal was denied.  

The consolidated cases highlight tensions between public health concerns and election administration, with the court deferring to state authority and procedural timelines over plaintiffs’ constitutional arguments.
results.VR-SC-0078:
In *Thomas v. Andino* (Case No. 3:20-cv-01552-JMC), plaintiffs—including Mary Thomas, Nea Richard, Jeremy Rutledge, Trena Walker, Dr. Brenda Williams, and the nonpartisan organization The Family Unit, Inc.—filed a lawsuit in April 2020 challenging South Carolina’s absentee voting requirements amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The plaintiffs argued that two state laws unduly burdened their fundamental right to vote in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and the Voting Rights Act (VRA). First, the “Excuse Requirement” (S.C. Code § 7-15-320) limited absentee voting to specific categories of voters, such as those over 65 or with disabilities, excluding others who wished to avoid in-person voting due to pandemic risks. Second, the “Witness Requirement” (S.C. Code §§ 7-15-220, 380) mandated a third-party witness sign absentee ballot envelopes, which plaintiffs claimed was impossible for those living alone, particularly elderly and disabled voters.  

The case arose as South Carolina faced a surge in pandemic-related health risks, with plaintiffs emphasizing that the challenged laws disproportionately affected African-American voters, who comprised a majority of virus-related deaths in the state. The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to suspend these requirements for the June 2020 primaries and November general election, asserting irreparable harm from disenfranchisement or exposure to the virus. On May 25, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction against the Witness Requirement for the June primaries, ordering defendants to inform voters of the change. However, the state legislature later enacted a temporary law (S.C. Act 133) allowing all voters to request absentee ballots for the June primaries, which expired on July 1, 2020.  

In August 2020, defendants (state election officials) and intervenors (South Carolina Republican Party, Governor McMaster) filed motions for summary judgment, arguing that the plaintiffs lacked standing and that the Excuse and Witness Requirements were constitutional and lawful under state and federal law. The plaintiffs countered that the requirements violated Section 201 of the VRA as “tests or devices” and the ADA by discriminating against disabled voters. The court partially granted summary judgment in favor of defendants on the Excuse Requirement, finding plaintiffs had not demonstrated a severe burden under the Anderson-Burdick framework. On the Witness Requirement, the court deferred to state legislative authority, citing the state’s interest in election integrity.  

On September 18, 2020, the court issued a stay of proceedings, citing a related case (*Middleton v. Andino*, 3:20-cv-01730-JMC), where a preliminary injunction had already suspended the Witness Requirement for the November election. The stay was later extended, effectively halting further litigation until after the 2020 elections. By September 2020, most plaintiffs had been terminated from the case (e.g., Rutledge, Walker), and Governor McMaster was removed as a defendant. The court’s final rulings upheld the state’s election laws as constitutional, emphasizing the legislature’s role in regulating voting procedures and the lack of evidence showing the challenged requirements caused significant harm. The case underscores tensions between pandemic safety concerns and election administration, with the court ultimately deferring to state legislative decisions.
results.JC-MD-0017:
In April 2020, a group of pretrial detainees and a post-conviction prisoner at the Prince George’s County Jail (PGCDOC) filed a class action complaint and habeas corpus petition under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 against Mary Lou McDonough, the Director of the Department of Corrections, in her official capacity. The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments due to the jail’s failure to implement CDC-recommended measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and its inadequate medical care for symptomatic inmates. They sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction to enforce hygiene protocols, social distancing, and timely medical screening, as well as release for medically vulnerable detainees.  

The complaint detailed uncontrolled outbreaks, lack of free hygiene supplies, insufficient medical attention, and unsanitary isolation conditions. Plaintiffs highlighted systemic issues, including limited soap access, failure to isolate symptomatic individuals, and delayed testing. The court granted a TRO on May 21, 2020, requiring the jail to submit a plan for identifying, monitoring, and treating high-risk detainees. The TRO expired on June 22, 2020, after the court found no further emergency relief necessary.  

Defendant McDonough moved to dismiss the amended complaint, arguing that plaintiffs failed to exhaust administrative remedies and that the TRO was moot. The court denied the motion to stay the TRO pending appeal, finding no evidence of exhaustion or likelihood of success on the merits. The case proceeded with discovery, and in August 2020, the court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss, upholding the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive relief and class certification.  

A court-appointed inspector, Dr. Carlos Franco-Paredes, reviewed the facility and confirmed significant undertesting and challenges in maintaining social distancing. His report, however, noted the jail’s compliance with CDC guidelines in some respects, such as sanitation and quarantine measures. The plaintiffs’ claims centered on the jail’s deliberate indifference to the pandemic, while the defendant emphasized adherence to evolving CDC protocols and the necessity of lockdowns to curb transmission.  

The case remains active, with the court maintaining jurisdiction to address ongoing compliance with public health standards and constitutional rights in the detention facility.
results.IM-FL-0029:
In April 2020, 34 detained immigrants (later expanded to 58 plaintiffs) filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officials, alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment due process rights. The plaintiffs, housed at three Florida detention centers (Krome, Glades, and BTC), claimed that ICE’s failure to implement Centers for Disease Control (CDC) guidelines during the COVID-19 pandemic exposed them to unconstitutional health risks. They argued that overcrowded conditions, cohort quarantines, and lack of hygiene supplies made social distancing impossible, violating ICE’s own detention standards and CDC recommendations for managing infectious diseases in correctional facilities.  

The court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) on April 30, 2020, requiring ICE to reduce detention populations to 75% capacity, provide masks and hygiene supplies, and evaluate detainees for release. After a May 2020 hearing, the TRO was extended and clarified to permit transfers only after individualized assessments of release eligibility. In June 2020, the court issued a preliminary injunction, mandating further compliance with CDC protocols, including separating confirmed and unconfirmed COVID-19 cases, ensuring unrestricted access to cleaning materials, and educating detainees about the virus. A special master was appointed to monitor compliance and found ICE had partially adhered to the orders but continued to cohort detainees and conduct unsafe transfers.  

In July 2020, the court denied class certification for the habeas corpus release claim but certified a class for conditions-of-confinement claims. Petitioners later filed a settlement agreement in June 2021, which required ICE to follow CDC and ICE pandemic response guidelines, implement vaccination protocols, maintain population density below 75% capacity, and provide educational materials about health measures. The settlement also allowed for continued individual habeas petitions. ICE contested the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment in January 2021, but the court found ongoing violations of detention standards. The case concluded with a settlement that remains court-enforced, emphasizing ICE’s obligation to prioritize detainee health during the pandemic.
